english: to lift; carry on the shoulders

etymology.description: semantic: 𦥑/臼 ‘pair of hands’ + semantic: 廾 ‘pair of hands’; upper was originally 𦥑, so 臼 as ‘mortar’ is a false friend.
etymology.interpretation: Depicts two sets of hands working together to raise a load, conveying the act of lifting or carrying on the shoulders. The top was originally the hand component 𦥑, later misread as the mortar 臼.

examples.chinese: 两人共舁重鼎(兩人共舁重鼎)。
examples.pinyin: Liǎng rén gòng yú zhòng dǐng.
examples.english: Two people together hoisted a heavy ding.

examples.chinese: 士卒舁伤者而行(士卒舁傷者而行)。
examples.english: The soldiers carried the wounded and moved on.

examples.chinese: 民夫舁柴入城(民夫舁柴入城)。
examples.english: Porters carried firewood into the city.
